content.text: The Rule
Your body has limits. How much you can carry is determined by Chrome — your physical augmentation and raw body power.
Carry Capacity = 5 + (Chrome × 3) weight units.
Chrome Carry Capacity

The difference matters. A Chrome 4 contractor carries their weapons, armor, and maybe a med kit. A Chrome 10 contractor carries all that plus a teammate’s spare ammo, a full harvest load, and the salvage nobody else could lift. A Chrome 15 augmented brute hauls equipment that would normally require a vehicle.
Every item has a Weight value measured in units. Negligible items (coins, keys, ammo for a crossbow) have weight 0 — they don’t count unless you’re carrying absurd quantities.
Overencumbered
If you exceed your Carry Capacity:

• 1-5 units over: -1 to all physical checks. Speed reduced by 1 range band per round of movement. • 6-10 units over: -2 to all physical checks. Speed reduced by 2 range bands. Cannot dodge (Evasion halved, round down). • 11+ over: Cannot move faster than Adjacent. Cannot dodge. Cannot attack. You’re a turtle with debt.
Carry Weight and Harvesting
This is where the Chrome vs brains split matters.
Chrome determines how much you carry out. High Chrome contractors can haul more raw material from a harvest site. Each point of Carry Capacity above your equipped gear’s weight contributes to your
Available Harvest Carry — the space you have left for loot.

Interface and Edge determine how well you harvest. The harvesting check (see Harvesting & Crafting) uses relevant skills to determine the quality and value of what you extract. A high-Interface contractor with a steady hand and rift knowledge carves out the valuable organs, the rare crystal cores, the intact spell glands. A high-Edge contractor spots the thing everyone else missed — the hidden cache, the rare material, the component that’s worth ten times the obvious stuff.

The result: the Chrome 8 brute carries out a backpack full of generic rift meat. The Interface 6 channeler carries out three perfectly extracted spell glands worth more than the entire backpack. Both are correct. Both are needed. The ideal team has both.
Available Harvest Carry = Carry Capacity - Equipped Gear Weight
Each unit of Available Harvest Carry lets you bring back 1 harvest unit from a mission. Harvest units are then valued based on your harvesting check results.
What Augments Cost
Augments are your primary progression system. Each augment has a
purchase cost (the augment itself) plus an installation cost (someone has to put it in you). Both come out of your pocket.
Augment prices by tier (ranges from the Augment Trees):
Tier Augment Cost Typical What It Range Represents
T1 100-250 cr \~200 cr Entry-level mods. Basic implants. Your body’s first real changes.
T2 300-500 cr \~400 cr Serious augmentation. Your body is adapting to significant modification.
T3 450-700 cr \~600 cr Advanced systems. Multiple integrated modifications working together.
T4 700-1,200 cr \~950 cr High-end hardware. Your body is more machine/magic than stock at this point.
T5 (Mastery) — Free Passive bonus. No purchase needed — your body has fully integrated the tree. ----------------- ----------------- ----------------- -----------------
Total cost to reach Mastery in one tree (10 augments):
You need 10 augments to unlock T5 Mastery. Assuming a mix of tiers:

• 3× T1 (\~600 cr) + 3× T2 (\~1,200 cr) + 2× T3 (\~1,200 cr) + 2× T4 (\~1,900 cr) = \~4,900 cr in augments alone • Installation (Licensed Clinic): 10 × 250 cr = 2,500 cr • Installation (Team Chrome Tech): Free • Total with clinic: \~7,400 cr. Total with Chrome Tech: \~4,900 cr.
That’s roughly 10-15 missions worth of saving at early-game pay rates. Mastering a tree is a campaign-long investment. Having a Chrome Tech on the team saves you almost half the cost.
The Augment Decision
Every augment purchase is a trade-off against every other use of money:
• That 400 cr T2 augment is also 13 days of Apartment rent  • That 950 cr T4 augment is also 6 Scar treatments at a Street Doc  • That 250 cr installer fee is also 5 encounters of Magi Sniper ammo
Contractors who rush augments go hungry. Contractors who never augment fall behind. The sweet spot is somewhere in between, and finding it is half the game.
Installation Complications
When an installation complication occurs (see Services below), the augment still installs but malfunctions:
d6 Malfunction
1-2 Intermittent. Augment works 50% of the time (flip a coin each encounter). Repair cost: 50 cr.
3-4 Painful. Augment works but causes -1 to all checks for 24 hours post-installation. No repair needed, just time.

5-6 Rejection Risk. Augment works but your body fights it. Take 1d4 damage (unresistable) and +2 Toxicity. If not treated within 48 hours, augment must be removed and reinstalled. ----------------------------------- -----------------------------------

New contractors receive their Kit’s starting gear plus 100 credits (modified by Kit — Negotiator gets +100 cr, some Kits get +0). This is your first and last handout.
Suggested first purchases (after Kit gear):

• Med Patches (25 cr each) — always carry at least 2  • Ammo for your ranged weapon (50 cr) — if applicable  • Breather Mask (100 cr) — if heading into a rift immediately  • Save the rest — you’ll need it for rent
After Session 1, every credit comes from contracts. Budget accordingly.

“Equipment is provided at the contractor’s expense. Equipment damaged during contracted operations may be eligible for partial reimbursement pending review of the incident report, damage assessment, contractor conduct evaluation, and prevailing corporate policy. Average review period: 8-14 business weeks. Average approval rate: 6%. Carry a spare.“
“The weapon you buy is the weapon everyone has. The weapon you modify is the weapon nobody expects. And the weapon a real crafter builds? That’s the weapon that comes home when you don’t.“
Modification Philosophy

Stock gear keeps you alive. Modified gear keeps you alive better. Every mod is a tactical choice — not a flat power increase, but a trade-off that shifts how a weapon or piece of armor performs. A scope makes your rifle deadlier at range but doesn’t help in melee. A quick-release mag lets you reload for free once, but it doesn’t add damage. Living armor hurts anything that grabs you, but you can never take it off.

Mods are the gear layer of the customization stack: Kit Abilities define how you fight. Augments define what your body can do. Mods define what your equipment can do. All three feed the same character identity — and all three cost credits.
Mod Slots
Every piece of gear has a mod slot count based on its complexity and size. You can only install mods up to your slot limit.

Mod Types
Every mod has a type that determines who can install it and whether it can be removed.
Type Install Removable? Description Requirement
Mechanical Tech T2+ Yes — 1 Bolted, screwed, downtime mounted. Sights, activity, mod grips, stocks, recovered intact plates. Physical attachments.
Chemical Crafting T2+ No — permanent, Coatings, consumed on infusions, acid application treatments, material bonding. Changes the gear’s composition.
Biological Crafting T3+ No — permanent, Living materials living organism grafted onto bonded to gear equipment. Symbiotic organisms, rift-grown tissue, reactive membranes.
Rift Crafting T3+ No — permanent, Rift energy bound dimensional into the gear’s energy infused structure. Volatile. Adds Toxicity costs.

Neural Crafting T2+, Swap during Electronic/neural Interface 3+ downtime, old mod interfaces that deactivated (not connect gear to the destroyed) user’s augments. ----------------- ----------------- ----------------- -------------------
Mechanical mods are the bread and butter. Anyone with Tech T2 can install them. They can be removed and reused. Swapping a scope takes a downtime activity.

Chemical, Biological, and Rift mods are permanent. Once applied, they’re part of the gear forever. If you want a different one, you need a new weapon. This is intentional — these mods change what the gear is, not what’s attached to it.
Neural mods split the difference. They’re electronic, so they can be swapped, but they require specialized knowledge to install and the old mod goes dormant (not destroyed) when replaced.

Professional Shops exist for crews without a crafter. The 50% installation fee is the price of convenience — and another reason having a crafter on the crew saves money.

Crafting System
The Crafter Role

A dedicated crafter is a crew force multiplier. They save the crew money on ammo, install mods without shop fees, maintain equipment, and can build things nobody sells. The crafter doesn’t need to swing a weapon well — their contribution is making everyone else’s weapons swing better.
Crafting Skill (Gated)
Crafting is a gated skill — you cannot attempt it without at least T1 training. It uses Interface as its stat.
Tier Capability
T1 — Tinkerer Craft basic ammunition. Repair damaged equipment. Identify materials and their uses.

T2 — Fabricator Install Mechanical, Chemical, and Neural mods. Craft special ammunition (AP, Incendiary, Rift-Tipped). Create basic consumables (Med Patches, Flares). Salvage mods from destroyed equipment (50% recovery chance).

T3 — Artificer Install Biological and Rift mods. Craft advanced consumables (Combat Stims, Scrubbers). Design custom mods (work with GM). Create gear from raw rift materials (Bone Edge weapons, Living Armor). Salvage at 75% recovery chance.

T4 — Master Artificer Create unique gear (one-of-a-kind weapons/armor with custom properties). Install any mod with auto-success (no check). Reverse-engineer enemy equipment. Create experimental mods that exceed normal parameters (GM collaboration). ----------------------------------- -----------------------------------

Material units are abstract. One unit of T2 Bio materials might be a Bloom Spitter’s toxin gland, a Stalker’s nerve cluster, or a vial of refined Char residue. The GM determines what’s available based on what the crew harvests.
The Crafter Economy
Why have a crafter on the crew?
Service Without Crafter With Crafter
Install Mechanical Mod  50% install fee at shop Free (crafter does it) (100-175 cr)
Install                 50% install fee at shop Free Chemical/Bio/Rift Mod   (100-350 cr)
Craft Ammo              Buy at retail           Craft at \~40-50% retail cost
Craft Consumables       Buy at retail           Craft at \~50% retail cost
Craft Special Ammo      Buy at retail (2-3×     Craft at \~60% retail base cost)              materials cost
Salvage Mods            Can’t — shop charges Free with 50-75% 200 cr                  success rate
Repair Equipment        Shop charges 50% gear   25% gear value in value                   materials

A T2 crafter saves the crew roughly 200-500 cr per downtime through installation fees, discounted ammo, and cheaper repairs. A T3 crafter saves more AND unlocks mods nobody else can access. Over a campaign, the crafter pays for their own training many times over.
